column1: Why do polynomial matrices appear in system theory?
column2: They encode multivariable linear dynamics algebraically.
column3: Needed for zero and factorization theory.

column2: A polynomial matrix with a polynomial inverse.
column3: Represents change of basis over a ring.
Used in Smith and Smith–McMillan forms.

column1: What is the Smith normal form?
column2: A diagonal form of a polynomial matrix under unimodular equivalence.
It defines the McMillan degree and transmission zeros.

column1: ⚠️ Why is this not linear algebra over a field?
column2: Polynomial matrices form modules over rings.

column1: What does 'unimodular' mean for a polynomial matrix?
column2: It has a polynomial inverse (equivalently, its determinant is a nonzero constant).
column3: Unimodular transformations are the ring-analogue of change-of-basis matrices.

column1: What does the Smith normal form reveal?
column2: Invariant factors of a polynomial matrix under unimodular equivalence.
column3: These invariants generalize gcd structure to matrices.

column1: How does Smith–McMillan form extend Smith form?
column2: It diagonalizes a rational matrix into ratios of polynomials, revealing pole/zero structure invariantly.
column3: Defines transmission zeros/poles and McMillan degree.

column1: Why does module language appear here (preview)?
column2: Polynomial matrices act on free modules over a ring, not vector spaces over a field.
column3: Unimodular equivalence is module isomorphism, not similarity.
